Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Nanostructured Solar Cells: Materials, Processes and Devices

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) project develops a novel, collaborative multidisciplinary program involving The University of South Dakota, South Dakota State University, The South Dakota School of Mines and Technology, and the National Center for Photovoltaics at the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL). Participating students will work toward the development of the next generation of solar energy devices, based on a broad background of academic training in chemistry, materials engineering, and electrical engineering. Student research opportunities include extended research rotations among the collaborating institutions and internships at NREL and in the solar energy industry. The goal of this program is to prepare students for leadership roles in education, research and development, and science-policy formulation. Reflecting this goal, the curriculum will include formal training in research ethics, public communication, and educational outreach. The South Dakota IGERT will produce a technical workforce in the critically important area of renewable energy and develop science leaders who are broadly trained within a culture of solving large-scale problems through an interdisciplinary, collaborative approach. This IGERT will recruit and retain students in groups underrepresented in science and engineering through interactions with a site for Research Experiences for Undergraduates, interactions with the Northern Plains Undergraduate Research Center, and though a partnership with Sinte Gleska University. IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was for an interdisciplinary graduate student traineeship, engaging students and their faculty mentors from the disciplines of Materials Chemistry, Electrical Engineering, Physics, and Materials Science and Engineering. Faculty from three campuses in South Dakota: the University of South Dakota, South Dakota State University, and the South Dakota School of Mines and Technology, designed and executed the project.

Twenty-seven students particpated in the program with seventeen faculty mentors. The students completed cross-disciplinary coursework, conducted interdisciplinary research in nanostructured solar cells, and designed and executed outreach projects to share their results in public venues. The students published their work in peer-reviewed journals during execution of the project for a total of 80 journal articles authored by IGERT students. An IGERT student appeared as first author on 44 of the publications.

Of the twenty-seven students, seventeen have graduated with award of PhD, and eight are on track for degree completion in the near future. Two students withdrew from their doctoral programs and are employed as (1) a design engineer in the solar energy industry and (2) an R&D scientist for speciality chemicals. The seventeen students who have graduated are all employed in jobs relevant to their IGERT training. Nine are employed as postdoctoral fellows or research scientists in academic or government laboratories, two are in tenure-track university faculty positions, five are employed in the private sector as R&D scientists, and one is employed as a community college instructor.

The intent of the program was that students would be given added value through cross-disciplinary research collaboration, training in outreach, and engagement in additional professional development opportuities, in order to prepare them to contribute to advancements in science and technology within a wide breadth of employment options. A goal was that the program elements over and above what is typically required in a doctoral program would not increase the already considerable time-to-degree for typical STEM PhD programs. Rather, the additional program elements should facilitate timely degree completion while increasing the preparedness of the students for their next professional advance. Of the seventeen students who have completed their degree programs, the average time-to-degree was 5.25 years, not counting one outlier whose degree program was interupted for family reasons. The eight students who are still in-process are projected to graduate with times-to-degree similar to the average.

The successes of the program include training of twenty-seven students who have become sucessful in their own right, a multi-institutional cultural shift toward greater interdisciplinarity in graduate training programs, and on-going research collaborations across three campuses in South Dakota.
